awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Theory and Practice of Cryptosystems Secure Against Subversion
awd_abstract_narration:
The discipline of cryptography provides the basic digital tools used across the globe to ensure data privacy and authenticity. With the broad deployment of these tools--often invisibly embedded in commercial software or hardware--an unconventional but devastating type of cyberattacks have emerged. These attacks involve deploying a cleverly subverted version of a cryptographic tool that appears to function normally, but in fact deliberately reduces security in a covert way that is known only to the subverting party. Such an attack can be carried out by the author of a software package, the manufacturer of a hardware device, or a third party who has contrived to interfere with the deployed product. Recent high-profile incidents of this kind have highlighted the threat associated with these attacks. This project is a comprehensive study of security in this setting, including development of formal models that permit rigorous reasoning about security, design and analysis of new cryptographic tools that resist subversion, and explicit recommendations for hardening the existing cryptographic tools in widespread use.

The project is organized into three main threads. The first focuses on establishing cryptographic security models that expand on classical cryptographic models to adequately reflect malicious subversion attacks: in general, these models call for the design of cryptographic tools to be explicitly coupled with specification of black-box testing procedures so that the combination can guarantee security despite subversion attacks. The second effort pursues development of fundamental cryptographic primitives that achieve security in these new models and application of these primitives as building blocks to construct larger systems and protocols that retain security despite subversion. Finally, to transition these theoretical tools to practice, the project undertakes a practical effort to re-architect existing infrastructural tools, such as the IPSec, SSH and TLS protocols, to harden them against subversion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we investigated the hard problem of building cryptographic devices and protocols that can survive "subversion". This means that devices have been designed or altered so that the cryptographic implementation does not meet the specification. In practice this can happen by accident or when a manufacturer or attacker inserts a "backdoor" into a device to cause it to encrypt information improperly. This has happened a number of times in the real world, resulting in systems such as Virtual Private Networks that fail to properly encrypt data -- and that can be eavesdropped upon by attackers.

Our goal in this project was to investigate systems that are "robust" against such attacks: this means that even if an attacker controls most of the system, they can still produce good results. Our aim was both theoretical and practical. My collaborators primarily focused on the theoretical aspects of this problem, developing frameworks for building cryptosystems that can resist subversion, provided that a small part of the system (a "watchdog") remains correctly-implemented. My focus in this work was practical: to investigate real-world protocols and systems that are subject to subversion attacks, and to find practical techniques to make systems more robust against these attacks.

My results focused on several areas. In one result, we discovered flaws in the random number generator algorithm used in many real-world Virtual Private Network devices that allowed an attacker to decrypt all traffic. While this flaw was likely an accident by the manufacturer, it is indistinguishable from deliberate subversion. This gave us insight into the type of flaws that can occur in this setting, and the types of defenses that can protect against it.

In another work, we looked at the question of law-enforcement access to cryptosystems. In this setting, devices are deliberately built so that law enforcement can gain access to encrypted messages if they possess a warrant or other legal instrument. The challenge in this setting is that malicious parties can abuse the system (or be hacked into, and the attackers can then abuse the system.) To address this, we designed a system that resists abuse by rogue law enforcement agents or hackers: this abuse-resistant system places strict limits on the types of message (and number of messages) that an attacker can obtain. Moreover it provides some degree of transparency for the warrants presented into the system.

In a third result, we investigated subversion attacks on cryptographic "mining" hardware that is used in cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin. This hardware is used to both secure the Bitcoin network, and to gain access to new bitcoins. We showed that with some practical modifications, malicious manufacturers can make substantial amounts of money by diverting mining revenue into their own hands. Moreover, we presented techniques that both detect and defend against these attacks.

The goal of our research was to conduct a broad and applied investigation of the attacks and defense techniques that can defend against these subversion attacks. Our results were presented in a number of top computer security and cryptography conferences, including ACM CCS, Financial Cryptography, Eurocrypt and Usenix Security.
